Award.AwardTitle: CRI: II-EN: High-Fidelity Real-Time Avatars for Virtual and Mixed Reality

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Technology that can create compelling immersive virtual environments is now available on the general market. However, this technology has limitations. Important frontiers for virtual environments need high quality tracking equipment. One of these frontiers is the ability to build characters that move accurately in a virtual environment. A second frontier is the ability to explore large virtual environments using methods that seem natural. Our goal is to tailor these methods to the individual user. This research proposal will equip a lab with instrumentation that will make fundamental advances on these two problems. It will also train graduate students and provide research opportunities for a number of undergraduates.

This research will equip a laboratory with a high quality motion capture system that will allow the pursuit of novel scientific questions involving the perceptual fidelity of virtual environments, examine theoretical questions involving users and their relationship to their self-avatars, and determine how individual differences in users can be effectively utilized to provide better locomotion and navigation in virtual worlds. In particular, this equipment will enable research in how to design high fidelity virtual environments, and enable the understanding of the components of fidelity that facilitate learning and transfer of training, for which self-avatars are a critical component. Likewise, the equipment will enable significant progress in locomotion methods for improved navigation and wayfinding in large virtual environments by allowing examination of how spatial information sources are used by individuals as they move through virtual worlds.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project acquired infrastructure that allows us to determine how to build better virtual environments. The infrastructure was a high quality motion capture system. This type of system is used to track the motion of a person as they move in a room, similar to a video camera. The difference is that the system can use the information it tracks to make graphical characters in a virtual environment move like the person being tracked is moving. This type of system is used to allow people to have a character in a virtual environment that represents their actions and moves like they move. The specific type of equipment is needed because we want the tracking to have high accuracy and small delay between the person moving the character in the virtual environment moving.


This type of system allows us to do research on how to build better virtual environments in important ways. Cheaper equipment can do the same thing, but it comes with less accuracy and often more delay. We would like to know how the cost of the system trades off against the accuracy and delay of the system when people are learning, training, and experiencing virtual environments. Determining precise bounds on this can tell us how quickly we will be able to obtain affordable, compelling virtual experiences available on the consumer market. Also, a high quality motion capture system allows us to conduct more thorough experiments governing how people move in large virtual environments when the the tracked space in the real world is limited. By understanding how physical space constrains our movements in virtual space, we are able to build better simulations and develop better virtual environments.

This infrastructure and the research it enables has value to society because because many of the applications we focus on deal with learning and training in virtual environments. Virtual environments can provide low-cost opportunities to experience situations where the cost or complexity of experiencing them in the real world is large. This infrastructure shows how to design better virtual environments for these applications. The infrastructure is also used to teach students, from graduate students to high school students, in cutting edge methods of science and technology. The work it enables is multi-disciplinary, allows students to understand a breadth of problems from multiple points of view.
